articles.headline: How Debt Can Destroy a Budding Relationship
articles.snippet: Because one person’s debt becomes a shared responsibility in marriage, when do you reveal a substantial liability?
articles.abstract: Because one person’s debt becomes a shared responsibility in marriage, when do you reveal a substantial liability?
articles.lead_paragraph: Nobody likes unpleasant surprises, but when Allison Brooke Eastman’s fiancé found out four months ago just how high her student loan debt was, he had a particularly strong reaction: he broke off the engagement within three days.

articles.headline: Syria’s Solidarity With Islamists Ends at Home
articles.snippet: The country, which had sought to allow religious figures a greater role in public life, has reversed course.
articles.abstract: The country, which had sought to allow religious figures a greater role in public life, has reversed course.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria  This country, which had sought to show solidarity with Islamist groups and allow religious figures a greater role in public life, has recently reversed course, moving forcefully to curb the influence of Muslim conservatives in its mosques, public universities and charities.

articles.headline: Venerable Craft, Modern Practitioner
articles.snippet: A family business with roots in Italy steps away from some long-held traditions to survive and grow in a modern world.
articles.abstract: A family business with roots in Italy steps away from some long-held traditions to survive and grow in a modern world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Ambrosi sweeps into the restaurant kitchen, past sizzling chicken and buttery mashed potatoes, and goes straight for the knives  carving knives and chef’s knives, paring knives and fillet knives, all made dull by clashes with flesh and bone. He picks them up and replaces them with identical twins.

articles.headline: 30 False Fronts Won Contracts for Blackwater
articles.snippet: The security firm created shell companies to obtain U.S. contracts after it was criticized for its conduct in Iraq, investigators said.
articles.abstract: The security firm created shell companies to obtain U.S. contracts after it was criticized for its conduct in Iraq, investigators said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Blackwater Worldwide created a web of more than 30 shell companies or subsidiaries in part to obtain millions of dollars in American government contracts after the security company came under intense criticism for reckless conduct in Iraq, according to Congressional investigators and former Blackwater officials.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Modified Salmon Is Safe, F.D.A. Says
articles.snippet: The assessment makes it more likely that the fish will become the first genetically modified animal to enter the American food supply.
articles.abstract: The assessment makes it more likely that the fish will become the first genetically modified animal to enter the American food supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: A salmon genetically engineered to grow quickly is safe to eat and poses little risk to the environment, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

articles.headline: The Struggle for What We Already Have
articles.snippet: The angst over net neutrality reaches from boardrooms to living rooms, but take heart: companies will breach its principles at their own peril. Consumers have come to expect an open Internet.
articles.abstract: The angst over net neutrality reaches from boardrooms to living rooms, but take heart: companies will breach its principles at their own peril. Consumers have come to expect an open Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: For something that seems so simple and straightforward, “net neutrality” has sure created one big mess.

articles.headline: On Economy, Democrats Face a Lack of Unity
articles.snippet: Democrats have yet to find a unifying message to address the economy and are scrambling to come up with job-creating remedies before voters go to the polls.
articles.abstract: Democrats have yet to find a unifying message to address the economy and are scrambling to come up with job-creating remedies before voters go to the polls.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Democrats are entering the fall sprint to the midterm elections lacking a unifying message to address the lackluster economy, scrambling to come up with further job-creating remedies and out of time to show substantial results before voters go to the polls.

articles.headline: Spotlight Shifts to Shallow-Water Wells
articles.snippet: A platform fire this week brings new scrutiny to the more than 3,000 shallow-water platforms operating in the gulf.
articles.abstract: A platform fire this week brings new scrutiny to the more than 3,000 shallow-water platforms operating in the gulf.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, thousands of oil and gas platforms have operated quietly in the shallower waters of the Gulf of Mexico, largely forgotten by the public and government regulators.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Alaska Winner, Lover of Privacy, Loses His Own
articles.snippet: Joe Miller, who won the Republican primary, has devoted his life to institutions and isolation.
articles.abstract: Joe Miller, who won the Republican primary, has devoted his life to institutions and isolation.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — The man with the best chance of becoming the next senator from Alaska lives at the end of a long gravel road here at the edge of the continent. Tribulation Trail is the name of his street. Signs warn against trespassing. A dog’s baritone bark rattles the aspens when car wheels, unexpected, churn the driveway.

articles.headline: Florida’s High-Speed Answer to a Foreclosure Mess
articles.snippet: Florida has set up foreclosure-only courts to reduce a huge backlog, but borrowers’ lawyers are critical of the process.
articles.abstract: Florida has set up foreclosure-only courts to reduce a huge backlog, but borrowers’ lawyers are critical of the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEN days from now, a four-bedroom house on a cul-de-sac in Middleburg, Fla., is scheduled to be auctioned off at the Clay County courthouse, 25 miles south of Jacksonville.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: In Middle East Peace Talks, Clinton Faces a Crucial Test
articles.snippet: The talks could cement the legacy of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton as a diplomat, or pose risks to any political ambitions she may harbor.
articles.abstract: The talks could cement the legacy of Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton as a diplomat, or pose risks to any political ambitions she may harbor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For much of her tenure as secretary of state, Hillary Rodham Clinton has been less an architect than an advocate for the Obama administration’s Middle East policy. With the resumption of direct talks last week, she now has no choice but to plunge into the rough and tumble of peacemaking.

articles.headline: After Bargains of Recession, Air Fares Soar
articles.snippet: Air fares have marched steadily upward in recent months and are now close to pre-recession levels  and that’s not even counting all the new fees that airlines have introduced lately.
articles.abstract: Air fares have marched steadily upward in recent months and are now close to pre-recession levels  and that’s not even counting all the new fees that airlines have introduced lately.
articles.lead_paragraph: Air fares have marched steadily upward in recent months and are now close to pre-recession levels  and that’s not even counting all the fees that airlines have introduced lately.

articles.headline: His Corporate Strategy: The Scientific Method
articles.snippet: J. Craig Venter wants to create creatures — bacteria, algae or even plants — to carry out industrial tasks and displace fossil fuels.
articles.abstract: J. Craig Venter wants to create creatures — bacteria, algae or even plants — to carry out industrial tasks and displace fossil fuels.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO

articles.headline: BB? AAA? Disclosure Tells Us More
articles.snippet: Through a proposed rule change, the S.E.C. wants to reduce investors’ reliance on ratings of mortgage pools.
articles.abstract: Through a proposed rule change, the S.E.C. wants to reduce investors’ reliance on ratings of mortgage pools.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR investors who believe the credit rating agencies have escaped responsibility for sins committed during the mortgage mayhem, the wrist slap last week of Moody’s Investors Service by the Securities and Exchange Commission was just the last in a long line of missed opportunities.

articles.headline: Democrats Plan Political Triage to Retain House
articles.snippet: The party is poised to redirect money from vulnerable incumbents to lawmakers who appear to be in the strongest position to fend off their challengers.
articles.abstract: The party is poised to redirect money from vulnerable incumbents to lawmakers who appear to be in the strongest position to fend off their challengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As Democrats brace for a November wave that threatens their control of the House, party leaders are preparing a brutal triage of their own members in hopes of saving enough seats to keep a slim grip on the majority.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Attack Shows Lasting Threat to U.S. in Iraq
articles.snippet: A coordinated attack on one of the main military commands in Baghdad punctuated a sharp rise in violence as the United States declared an official end to its combat mission.
articles.abstract: A coordinated attack on one of the main military commands in Baghdad punctuated a sharp rise in violence as the United States declared an official end to its combat mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Insurgents mounted a coordinated attack on one of the main military commands in Baghdad on Sunday, briefly drawing fire from American soldiers, an event that underscored the ambiguity of the American military’s role in Iraq.
articles.byline: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and DURAID ADNAN

articles.headline: Former H.P. Chief May Move to Oracle
articles.snippet: For Mark V. Hurd, landing a top position at Oracle would be a quick rebound after a tumultuous exit.
articles.abstract: For Mark V. Hurd, landing a top position at Oracle would be a quick rebound after a tumultuous exit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark V. Hurd, who was forced to resign as Hewlett-Packard’s top executive last month after an investigation into a sexual harassment charge found that he had manipulated his expenses, is in talks with Oracle about a top executive position there, according to a person briefed on the matter.

articles.headline: Housing Woes Bring a New Cry: Let the Market Fall
articles.snippet: Some economists and analysts urge a dose of shock therapy that would shift benefits to future homeowners from current ones: Let the housing market crash.
articles.abstract: Some economists and analysts urge a dose of shock therapy that would shift benefits to future homeowners from current ones: Let the housing market crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unexpectedly deep plunge in home sales this summer is likely to force the Obama administration to choose between future homeowners and current ones, a predicament officials had been eager to avoid.

articles.headline: From Viral Video to Billboard 100
articles.snippet: The “Bed Intruder Song” was a rare case of a product of Web culture jumping the species barrier and becoming a pop hit.
articles.abstract: The “Bed Intruder Song” was a rare case of a product of Web culture jumping the species barrier and becoming a pop hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Viral videos tend to have a short lifespan online. The best ones might attract a few million views on YouTube and get a mention on a late-night talk show before fading into oblivion.

articles.headline: The Glut of Shows Unwatched
articles.snippet: Television, which was once the brain-dead part of the day, has become one more thing that requires time, attention and discernment.
articles.abstract: Television, which was once the brain-dead part of the day, has become one more thing that requires time, attention and discernment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The great thing about modern technology is that you never have to miss anything on television. That’s also the terrible thing about it.

articles.headline: For G.O.P., Tea Party Wields a Double-Edged Sword
articles.snippet: The Tea Party fervor is expected to help Republicans in November, but it may also create problems for them.
articles.abstract: The Tea Party fervor is expected to help Republicans in November, but it may also create problems for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Christine O’Donnell, running in Delaware to be the Republican nominee for the Senate seat once held by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., is a perennial candidate with a history of financial problems, including unpaid taxes and a home in foreclosure. Representative Michael N. Castle, her opponent in the primary, is a veteran congressman and former governor who has won statewide elections more than 10 times.

articles.headline: Some See a Ploy as Craigslist Blocks Sex Ads
articles.snippet: Since blocking its “adult services” ads as the weekend began, Craigslist has refused to discuss its motivations.
articles.abstract: Since blocking its “adult services” ads as the weekend began, Craigslist has refused to discuss its motivations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Craigslist, by shutting off its “adult services” section and slapping a “censored” label in its place, may be engaging in a high-stakes stunt to influence public opinion, some analysts say.

articles.headline: Even Hit Like ‘Kick-Ass’ Can Seem Like Miss at Debut
articles.snippet: The film “Kick-Ass” fell short in its opening weekend, and bloggers wrote it off as a flop. Never mind that this $15 million film went on to sell almost $100 million in tickets.
articles.abstract: The film “Kick-Ass” fell short in its opening weekend, and bloggers wrote it off as a flop. Never mind that this $15 million film went on to sell almost $100 million in tickets.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  In early April, as Lionsgate prepared to release “Kick-Ass,” the movie capital buzzed that the film looked to be a smash hit. Lionsgate had acquired it for just $15 million, and surveys that track audience interest projected a $30 million opening weekend.

articles.headline: Floods in Pakistan Carry the Seeds of Upheaval
articles.snippet: As devastating floods appear to widen divisions, Pakistani officials, some accused of ineptitude and favoritism, are trying to repair the political damage.
articles.abstract: As devastating floods appear to widen divisions, Pakistani officials, some accused of ineptitude and favoritism, are trying to repair the political damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: THATA SIAL, Pakistan  When the governor of Punjab Province arrived recently in this small town with truckloads of relief goods for flood victims, his visit was as much a political mission as a humanitarian one. His message to the hundred or so displaced people gathered under an awning was that the government was there for them.

articles.headline: Some Newspapers, Tracking Readers Online, Shift Coverage
articles.snippet: Because of technological advances, newspapers can make more scientific decisions about allocating their resources.
articles.abstract: Because of technological advances, newspapers can make more scientific decisions about allocating their resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: In most businesses, not knowing how well a particular product is performing would be almost unthinkable. But newspapers have always been a peculiar business, one that has stubbornly, proudly clung to a sense that focusing too much on the bottom line can lead nowhere good.

articles.headline: American Muslims Ask, Will We Ever Belong?
articles.snippet: The furor over a proposed center near ground zero has many worried about their place in American society.
articles.abstract: The furor over a proposed center near ground zero has many worried about their place in American society.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nine years after the attacks of Sept. 11, many American Muslims made concerted efforts to build relationships with non-Muslims, to make it clear they abhor terrorism, to educate people about Islam and to participate in interfaith service projects. They took satisfaction in the observations by many scholars that Muslims in America were more successful and assimilated than Muslims in Europe.

articles.headline: Congressional Charities Pulling In Corporate Cash
articles.snippet: At least two dozen charities that lawmakers or their families helped create or run routinely accept donations from businesses seeking to influence them.
articles.abstract: At least two dozen charities that lawmakers or their families helped create or run routinely accept donations from businesses seeking to influence them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Representative Joe Baca has achieved near celebrity status in his suburban Los Angeles district, as much for his record of giveaways  Thanksgiving turkeys, college scholarships, spare boots for firefighters  as for anything he has done in Congress.

articles.headline: Obama Offers a Transit Plan to Create Jobs
articles.snippet: President Obama, looking to jump-start the economy, called on Congress to approve a far-reaching plan to rebuild and modernize transportation over the next six years.
articles.abstract: President Obama, looking to jump-start the economy, called on Congress to approve a far-reaching plan to rebuild and modernize transportation over the next six years.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE  President Obama, looking to stimulate a sluggish economy and create jobs, called Monday for Congress to approve major upgrades to the nation’s roads, rail lines and runways  part of a six-year plan that would cost tens of billions of dollars and create a government-run bank to finance innovative transportation projects.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mary Williams Walsh
